functions.description:
Use `v-bind` to links CSS values to dynamic Vue component state. The syntax works with `<script setup>`, and supports JavaScript expressions, which must be wrapped in quotes.

The actual value will be compiled into a hashed CSS custom property, so the CSS is still static.
functions.name: v-bind

pseudo-classes.description: Make a rule that targets child components.
pseudo-classes.name: deep

pseudo-classes.description: In v3 child scoped styles are **not** affecting slot content by default. To explicitly target slot content, the `::v-slotted()` (shorthand: `:slotted()`) pseudo element can be used.
pseudo-classes.name: slotted

pseudo-classes.description: Use `::v-global()` (shorthand: `:global()`) pseudo element to make a one-off global rule within scoped `<style>` block.
pseudo-classes.name: global

pseudo-elements.description:
Make a rule that targets child components.

**Note: usage without arguments is deprecated since Vue 3.0.**
pseudo-elements.name: v-deep

pseudo-elements.description: Make a rule that targets child components.
pseudo-elements.name: v-deep

pseudo-elements.description: In v3 child scoped styles are **not** affecting slot content by default. To explicitly target slot content, the `::v-slotted()` (shorthand: `:slotted()`) pseudo element can be used.
pseudo-elements.name: v-slotted

pseudo-elements.description: Use `::v-global()` (shorthand: `:global()`) pseudo element to make a one-off global rule within scoped `<style>` block.
pseudo-elements.name: v-global

attributes.description: The `data-*` global attributes form a class of attributes called custom data attributes, that allow proprietary information to be exchanged between the HTML and its DOM representation by scripts.
attributes.name: data-*

attributes.description: Directives are special attributes with the `v-` prefix. Directive attribute values are expected to be a single JavaScript expression (with the exception of `v-for` and `v-on`). A directive's job is to reactively apply side effects to the DOM when the value of its expression changes.
attributes.name: Vue directive

attributes.description:
Attaches an event listener to the element. The event type is denoted by the argument. The expression can be a method name, an inline statement, or omitted if there are modifiers present.

When used on a normal element, it listens to *native DOM events* only. When used on a custom element component, it listens to *custom events* emitted on that child component.

When listening to native DOM events, the method receives the native event as the only argument. If using inline statement, the statement has access to the special `$event` property: `v-on:click="handle('ok', $event)"`.

`v-on` also supports binding to an object of event/listener pairs without an argument. Note when using the object syntax, it does not support any modifiers.
attributes.name: v-on alias

attributes.description:
Dynamically bind one or more attributes, or a component prop to an expression.

When used to bind the `class` or `style` attribute, it supports additional value types such as Array or Objects. See linked guide section below for more details.

When used for prop binding, the prop must be properly declared in the child component.

When used without an argument, can be used to bind an object containing attribute name-value pairs. Note in this mode `class` and `style` does not support Array or Objects.
attributes.name: v-bind alias

attributes.description: Denote named slots or slots that expect to receive props.
attributes.name: v-slot alias

attributes.description: Denote named slots or slots that expect to receive props.
attributes.name: slot

attributes.description: `ref` is used to register a reference to an element or a child component. The reference will be registered under the parent component's `$refs` object. If used on a plain DOM element, the reference will be that element; if used on a child component, the reference will be component instance.
attributes.name: ref

attributes.description:
The `key` special attribute is primarily used as a hint for Vue's virtual DOM algorithm to identify VNodes when diffing the new list of nodes against the old list. Without keys, Vue uses an algorithm that minimizes element movement and tries to patch/reuse elements of the same type in-place as much as possible. With keys, it will reorder elements based on the order change of keys, and elements with keys that are no longer present will always be removed/destroyed.

Children of the same common parent must have **unique keys**. Duplicate keys will cause render errors.

The most common use case is combined with `v-for`.
attributes.name: key

elements.description: `<slot>` serve as content distribution outlets in component templates. `<slot>` itself will be replaced.
elements.name: slot

vue-components.description: A "meta component" for rendering dynamic components. The actual component to render is determined by the `is` prop.
vue-components.name: Component

props.description: An HTML tag name, a Component name or Component class reference.
props.name: is

props.description: Used to automatically generate transition CSS class names. e.g. `name: 'fade'` will auto expand to `.fade-enter`, `.fade-enter-active`, etc.
props.name: name

props.description: Whether to apply transition on initial render.
props.name: appear

props.description: Whether to apply CSS transition classes. Defaults to `true`. If set to `false`, will only trigger JavaScript hooks registered via component events.
props.name: css

props.description: Specifies the type of transition events to wait for to determine transition end timing. Available values are `"transition"` and `"animation"`. By default, it will automatically detect the type that has a longer duration.
props.name: type

props.description: Specifies the duration of transition. By default, Vue waits for the first `transitionend` or `animationend` event on the root transition element.
props.name: duration

vue-components.description: `<transition>` serve as transition effects for *single* element/component. The `<transition>` only applies the transition behavior to the wrapped content inside; it doesn't render an extra DOM element, or show up in the inspected component hierarchy.
vue-components.name: Transition

props.description: Controls the timing sequence of leaving/entering transitions. Available modes are `"out-in"` and `"in-out"`; defaults to simultaneous.
props.name: mode

values.description: Current element transitions out first, then when complete, the new element transitions in.
values.name: out-in

values.description: New element transitions in first, then when complete, the current element transitions out.
values.name: in-out

vue-components.description:
`<transition-group>` serve as transition effects for *multiple* elements/components. The `<transition-group>` renders a real DOM element. By default it renders a `<span>`, and you can configure what element it should render via the `tag` attribute.

Note that every child in a `<transition-group>` must be *uniquely keyed* for the animations to work properly.
vue-components.name: TransitionGroup

props.description: Overwrite CSS class applied during moving transition
props.name: moveClass

vue-components.description:
When wrapped around a dynamic component, `<keep-alive>` caches the inactive component instances without destroying them. Similar to `<transition>`, `<keep-alive>` is an abstract component: it doesn’t render a DOM element itself, and doesn’t show up in the component parent chain.

When a component is toggled inside `<keep-alive>`, its `activated` and `deactivated` lifecycle hooks will be invoked accordingly.

Primarily used to preserve component state or avoid re-rendering.
vue-components.name: KeepAlive

props.description: Only components with matching names will be cached.
props.name: include

props.description: Any component with a matching name will not be cached.
props.name: exclude

props.description: The maximum number of component instances to cache.
props.name: max

vue-components.description: Suspense is a special component that renders a fallback content instead of child components until a condition is met. This condition is usually async operation happening in the components setup function.
vue-components.name: Suspense

slots.description: Content to render once async operation is finished
slots.name: default

slots.description: Content to render during async operation
slots.name: fallback

vue-components.description: Teleport provides a clean way to control under which parent in our DOM a piece of HTML will be rendered, without having to resort to global state or splitting elements into two components.
vue-components.name: Teleport

props.description: A valid query selector, or an HTMLElement (if used in a browser environment). Specifies a target element where `<teleport>` content will be moved
props.name: to

props.description: Used to disable the `<teleport>`'s functionality, which means that its slot content will not be moved anywhere and instead be rendered where you specified the `<teleport>` in the surrounding parent component.
props.name: disabled

vue-directives.description: Updates the element’s `textContent`. If you need to update the part of `textContent`, you should use `{{ Mustache }}` interpolations.
vue-directives.name: text

vue-directives.description: Updates the element’s `innerHTML`. *Note that the contents are inserted as plain HTML - they will not be compiled as Vue templates*. If you find yourself trying to compose templates using `v-html`, try to rethink the solution by using components instead.
vue-directives.name: html

vue-directives.description:
Toggles the element’s `display` CSS property based on the truthy-ness of the expression value.

This directive triggers transitions when its condition changes.
vue-directives.name: show

vue-directives.description:
Conditionally render the element based on the truthy-ness of the expression value. The element and its contained directives / components are destroyed and re-constructed during toggles. If the element is a `<template>` element, its content will be extracted as the conditional block.

This directive triggers transitions when its condition changes.
vue-directives.name: if

vue-directives.description: Denote the "else block" for `v-if` or a `v-if/v-else-if` chain.
vue-directives.name: else

vue-directives.description: Denote the "else if block" for `v-if`. Can be chained.
vue-directives.name: else-if

vue-directives.description: Render the element or template block multiple times based on the source data. The directive’s value must use the special syntax `alias in expression` to provide an alias for the current element being iterated on. Alternatively, you can also specify an alias for the index (or the key if used on an Object). The default behavior of `v-for` will try to patch the elements in-place without moving them. To force it to reorder elements, you need to provide an ordering hint with the `key` special attribute.
vue-directives.name: for

vue-directives.description:
Attaches an event listener to the element. The event type is denoted by the argument. The expression can be a method name, an inline statement, or omitted if there are modifiers present.

When used on a normal element, it listens to *native DOM events* only. When used on a custom element component, it listens to *custom events* emitted on that child component.

When listening to native DOM events, the method receives the native event as the only argument. If using inline statement, the statement has access to the special `$event` property: `v-on:click="handle('ok', $event)"`.

`v-on` also supports binding to an object of event/listener pairs without an argument. Note when using the object syntax, it does not support any modifiers.

modifiers.description: Only trigger handler for left button mouse events.
modifiers.name: left

modifiers.description: Only trigger handler for right button mouse events.
modifiers.name: right

modifiers.description: Only trigger handler for middle button mouse events.
modifiers.name: middle

modifiers.description: Triggers mouse or keyboard event listeners only when the modifier key is pressed.
modifiers.name: System modifier key

modifiers.description: Allows control of the exact combination of system modifiers needed to trigger an event.
modifiers.name: exact

modifiers.description: Add event listener in capture mode.
modifiers.name: capture

modifiers.description: Only trigger handler if event was dispatched from this element.
modifiers.name: self

modifiers.description: attaches a DOM event with `{ passive: true }`.
modifiers.name: passive

vue-directives.name: on

vue-directives.description:
Dynamically bind one or more attributes, or a component prop to an expression.

When used to bind the `class` or `style` attribute, it supports additional value types such as Array or Objects. See linked guide section below for more details.

When used for prop binding, the prop must be properly declared in the child component.

When used without an argument, can be used to bind an object containing attribute name-value pairs. Note in this mode `class` and `style` does not support Array or Objects.

modifiers.description: Transform the kebab-case attribute name into camelCase.
modifiers.name: camel

modifiers.description: force a binding to be set as a DOM property.
modifiers.name: prop

modifiers.description: force a binding to be set as a DOM attribute.
modifiers.name: attr

vue-directives.name: bind

vue-directives.description: Create a two-way binding on a form input element or a component. For detailed usage and other notes, see the Guide section.

modifiers.description: Cast valid input string to numbers
modifiers.name: number

vue-directives.name: model

vue-directives.description: Skip compilation for this element and all its children. You can use this for displaying raw mustache tags. Skipping large numbers of nodes with no directives on them can also speed up compilation.
vue-directives.name: pre

vue-directives.description: This directive will remain on the element until the associated Vue instance finishes compilation. Combined with CSS rules such as `[v-cloak] { display: none }`, this directive can be used to hide un-compiled mustache bindings until the Vue instance is ready.
vue-directives.name: cloak

vue-directives.description: Memoize a sub-tree of the template. Can be used on both elements and components. The directive expects a fixed-length array of dependency values to compare for the memoization. If every value in the array was the same as last render, then updates for the entire sub-tree will be skipped.
vue-directives.name: memo

vue-directives.description: Render the element and component *once* only. On subsequent re-renders, the element/component and all its children will be treated as static content and skipped. This can be used to optimize update performance.
vue-directives.name: once

vue-directives.description: Deprecated in 3.1.0. Use [`is` attribute with `vue:` prefix](https://v3.vuejs.org/api/special-attributes.html#is) instead.
vue-directives.name: is

vue-dynamic-argument.description:
It is possible to use a JavaScript expression in a directive argument by wrapping it with square brackets. The expression's evaluated value will be used as the final value for the argument.

Dynamic arguments are expected to evaluate to a string, with the exception of `null`. The special value `null` can be used to explicitly remove the binding. Any other non-string value will trigger a warning.
vue-dynamic-argument.name: Dynamic directive argument

vue-file-top-elements.description: The top-level `<style>` element serves as a container for the component styles.
vue-file-top-elements.name: style

vue-file-top-elements.description: The top-level `<script>` element serves as a container for the component code.
vue-file-top-elements.name: script

vue-file-top-elements.description: The top-level `<template>` element serves as a container for the component template contents.
vue-file-top-elements.name: template
